issues.title: BUG: Memory leak in numpy.dot when using large float128 arrays in loop
issues.body:
### Describe the issue:

When repeatedly calling numpy.dot() inside a loop with large arrays of float128 dtype, memory usage increases continuously and is never released, even after deleting the arrays.

This behavior suggests a possible memory leak in the low-level BLAS implementation for extended precision types.
The same code works fine with float64.

### Reproduce the code example:

```python
import numpy as np

for i in range(10000):
    a = np.random.rand(1000, 1000).astype(np.float128)
    b = np.dot(a, a)
    del a, b  # Explicit deletion does not stop memory growth
```

### Error message:

```shell
No error message is displayed â€” the issue is an abnormal memory growth over time.

Monitoring with Windows Task Manager or top shows the process consuming several GB of memory after a few minutes.
```

### Python and NumPy Versions:

NumPy version: 2.0.2
Python version: 3.12.12

### Runtime Environment:

BLAS info: Intel(R) MKL 2023.2.1  
LAPACK info: Intel(R) MKL 2023.2.1  
CPU info: AMD Ryzen 7 5800H  


### Context for the issue:

I encountered this problem while running a Monte Carlo simulation where thousands of matrix multiplications are performed using extended precision (float128).

Over time, the memory usage grows linearly, which causes the system to slow down and eventually crash.

This prevents long-running scientific computations that require float128 precision from completing successfully.

issues.title: Unchecked memory allocations
issues.body:
In almost all cases, if a memory allocation in our C & C++ code fails, the failure is handled so that eventually a `MemoryError` exception is raised by Python. I think that is a general rule that we apply to all low-level code: failure to allocate memory should ultimately result in a Python exception and not crash the interpreter.

Here are a few places where we don't check for a memory allocation failure:

* https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/f39abd4ffbca44f01eec353115ffd2d7ad296fb2/numpy/_core/src/multiarray/dtype_transfer.c#L171-L173

* https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/f39abd4ffbca44f01eec353115ffd2d7ad296fb2/numpy/_core/src/multiarray/stringdtype/casts.cpp#L856-L861

* https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/f39abd4ffbca44f01eec353115ffd2d7ad296fb2/numpy/_core/src/multiarray/stringdtype/casts.cpp#L1117-L1118

* https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/f39abd4ffbca44f01eec353115ffd2d7ad296fb2/numpy/_core/src/umath/stringdtype_ufuncs.cpp#L1121

* https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/f39abd4ffbca44f01eec353115ffd2d7ad296fb2/numpy/_core/src/umath/stringdtype_ufuncs.cpp#L1243

* https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/f39abd4ffbca44f01eec353115ffd2d7ad296fb2/numpy/_core/src/umath/stringdtype_ufuncs.cpp#L1458

* https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/f39abd4ffbca44f01eec353115ffd2d7ad296fb2/numpy/_core/src/umath/stringdtype_ufuncs.cpp#L1577

The following uses of `std::unordered_set` in `unique.cpp` can throw an exception if an allocation fails, which will crash Python:

* https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/f39abd4ffbca44f01eec353115ffd2d7ad296fb2/numpy/_core/src/multiarray/unique.cpp#L212-L214

* https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/f39abd4ffbca44f01eec353115ffd2d7ad296fb2/numpy/_core/src/multiarray/unique.cpp#L220

(This was not an exhaustive search.)

issues.title: TYP: numpy allows a datetime array to be divided by another array
issues.body:
### Describe the issue:

If a numpy array has a datetime type, and is divided by another array, typecheckers are not picking that up as wrong.

### Reproduce the code example:

```python
from typing import reveal_type
import numpy as np

s = np.array([np.datetime64(f"2025-10-{d:02d}") for d in (23, 24, 25)], np.datetime64)
t = np.array([1, 2, 3])
reveal_type(s)
reveal_type(t)
reveal_type(s.__truediv__(t))

s / t
```

### Error message:

```shell
The type revealed of the division operation is `Any`
```

### Python and NumPy Versions:

python 3.12
numpy 2.3.4

### Type-checker version and settings:

pyright 1.1.407
mypy 1.18.2

### Additional typing packages.

Note:  This came up with `pandas-stubs`.  

We think the solution is to add an overload that returns `Never` .

issues.title: SIMD: unify SIMD kernel selection across NumPy and OpenBLAS/MKL
issues.body:
It might make sense to unify the selection of SIMD kernels used in both ufuncs (via our dispatching) and linalg (by third-party BLAS implementations). We use [runtime settings](https://numpy.org/doc/stable/reference/simd/build-options.html#runtime-dispatch) of `NPY_DISABLE_CPU_FEATURES` and `NPY_ENABLE_CPU_FEATURES`, OpenBLAS uses `OPENBLAS_CORETYPE`, I don't see [how MKL lets users](https://www.intel.com/content/www/us/en/docs/onemkl/developer-guide-windows/2025-2/managing-behavior-of-onemkl-with-env-vars.html) control the kernels used.

The use of environment variables makes sense since NumPy's dispatch is fixed at import time: function slots are set up to point to the appropriate kernels. So this could not be done via a context manager around the ufunc/linalg function call. But we could try to translate the feature use to OpenBLAS coretype before importing scipy_openblas at startup, or (going the other direction), layer `OPENBLAS_CORETYPE` on top of the NumPy feature selection logic.

BUG: C code generated by f2py is not C23 compliant
issues.body:
### Describe the issue:

Looks like the C code generated by f2py is not C23 compliant and fails to compile with gcc 15.

For instance, this can be seen trying to build scikits.odes-daepack on rolling linux distros that are already at gcc 15. Editing the `meson.build` file to include a 'c_std=c17' seems to fix the issue.

The problem seems to be triggered when generating functions that take a function as a parameter. The latter gets in the signature as `f2py_func()` that is a function taking an arbitrary number of parameters in C<23 but is not the same in C23 that wants a full signature.

`uv add scikits.odes` on a system with gcc 15.

N/A

issues.title: TYP: invalid default value documented on `array`'s `ndmax` parameter
issues.body:
### Describe the issue:

Hello from downstream, @jorenham !

first of: we also have a couple inspect-based tests in astropy intended to catch discrepancies between numpy signatures and our NEP 18 dispatch functions. Functions which didn't have signatures available at runtime were simply ignored, but your recent work has allowed finding many more issues with our NEP 18 implementations, so thanks a lot for that !

I'm seeing a small issue with gh-30138 though; `None` doesn't appear to be a valid value for `array`'s `ndmax` argument at runtime (an integer is expected). Instead, and based on my understanding of gh-29569, it seems the default value should actually be `0`.
It can be worked around in astropy alright, but it feels slightly off that I need to both re-expose the default value as `None` (granted, this part is imposed by *our* tests) *and* include logic in the implementation to handle this special case. issues.body:

`PyArray_NewFromDescr()` is [documented](https://numpy.org/devdocs/reference/c-api/array.html#c.PyArray_NewFromDescr) as stealing a reference to `descr`, and so to my understanding is expected to do so on success or error. issues.title: BUG: `numpy.dot()` returns inconsistent output on Linux versus MacOS

labels.name: 57 - Close?
labels.description: Issues which may be closable unless discussion continued

issues.body:
### Describe the issue:

While working on a bug in my project I noticed some strange behavior between Linux and MacOS with regards to the output of `numpy.dot()`.

On Linux, the output of a specific `numpy.dot()` operation (details in the code to reproduce) is (with NumPy 2.2.6)
`[-0.50000000000000011102 -0.50000000000000011102 -0.50000000000000000000]`
and on MacOS (ARM) the output is (with NumPy 2.3.4)
`[-0.50000000000000000000 -0.50000000000000011102 -0.50000000000000000000]`

In my limited testing capabilities I can confirm that the output from Mac and Linux with NumPy 1.26.4 is identical, but for at least NumPy >= 2.2.2 (I suspect this is actually >= 2.0.0 but haven't been able to test this) the outputs differ and are the demonstrated result.

### Reproduce the code example:

```python
import numpy as np

np.set_printoptions(precision=20, floatmode="fixed")

pos_i = np.array([0., 0., 0.], dtype=np.float64)

c = np.array([0.61550000000000071321, 1.06607727205864510900, 7.50000000000000000000], dtype=np.float64)

axinv = np.array(
    [
        [ 4.06173842404549123586e-01,  0.00000000000000000000e+00, 0.00000000000000000000e+00],
        [ 2.34504577250050944004e-01,  4.69009154500102054541e-01, 0.00000000000000000000e+00],
        [-4.97419495998112408112e-17, -4.97419495998112408112e-17, 6.66666666666666657415e-02],
    ], dtype=np.float64
)

dot = np.dot(pos_i-c,axinv)
print(dot)
```

### Error message:

```shell

```

### Python and NumPy Versions:

Python version (Linux) - 3.10.12
NumPy version (Linux) - 2.2.6

Python version (MacOS) - 3.12.10
NumPy version (MacOS) - 2.3.4

### Runtime Environment:

_No response_

### Context for the issue:

This result was noticed during a routine test in [QMCPACK PR 5345](https://github.com/QMCPACK/qmcpack/pull/5345) due to an operation using `numpy.floor()` which returned two different values for Linux and MacOS, leading to a test failure. We likely will be changing this test so that it is less sensitive to this sort of discrepancy, however the fact that this happened at all means we may need to revisit all of the occurrences of `numpy.dot()` in the codebase.

issues.title: BUG: `>f4` dtype looses NaN Payload
issues.body:
### Describe the issue:

This is very similar to a bug that was fixed in CPython 3.14: https://github.com/python/cpython/issues/130317

When creating an `f4` array with a NaN that has a payload, the payload gets normalized away.

Tested on 
 * Numpy 2.3.4
 * Python 3.14
 * Linux x86_64

### Reproduce the code example:

```python
import struct

import numpy as np

raw = b"\x7f\x80\x00\x01"

f = struct.unpack(">f", raw)[0]
round_tripped = np.fromiter([f], dtype=np.dtype(">f4")).tobytes()

# Fails because it round trips as b"\x7f\xc0\x00\x01"
assert raw == round_tripped


# if you try the same with a 64 bit float (f8), it works fine

raw = b"\x7f\xf8\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x01"

f = struct.unpack(">d", raw)[0]
round_tripped = np.fromiter([f], dtype=np.dtype(">f8")).tobytes()

# passes
assert raw == round_tripped
```

### Error message:

```shell
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<python-input-0>", line 11, in <module>
    assert raw == round_tripped
           ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
AssertionError
```

### Python and NumPy Versions:

2.3.4

                      'not_found': ['AVX512F',
                                    'AVX512CD',
                                    'AVX512_KNL',

                                    'AVX512_SKX',
                                    'AVX512_CLX',

The library I'm maintaining needs to transform Python floats into bytes. To speed up the process, I use numpy if available. As I now upgrade the library and its CI to run on Python 3.14 I noticed that the numpy and CPython implementations started to behave differently. Arguably, what CPython does is better as it's more consistent with double precision floats and what I find to be the expected behavior.

issues.title: BUG: Fail to compile wrap file generated with SWIG 4.4
issues.body:
### Describe the issue:

This simple `example.i` file:

```swig
%module example

%{
#include <numpy/arrayobject.h>
%}

%init
%{
    import_array();
%}
```

Compiles correctly when using SWIG 4.3:

```
$ swig -python example.i
$ gcc -c example_wrap.c $(pkgconf python3 --cflags) $(pkgconf numpy --cflags)
```

However, with SWIG 4.4, I get the following compilation error:

```
$ gcc -c example_wrap.c $(pkgconf python3 --cflags) $(pkgconf numpy --cflags)
example_wrap.c: In function â€˜SWIG_mod_execâ€™:
example_wrap.c:4148:3: error: returning â€˜void *â€™ from a function with return type â€˜intâ€™ makes integer from pointer without a cast [-Wint-conversion]
 4148 |   import_array();
      |   ^~~~~~~~~~~~
```

It seems that the problem stems from the change in how SWIG generates the wrap file. In version 4.4, the code generated by `_core/code_generators/generate_numpy_api.py` became incompatible. I traced the problem down and found that it can be resolved by amending the code starting at line 160:

```c
#define import_array() { \
  if (_import_array() < 0) { \
    PyErr_Print(); \
    PyErr_SetString( \
        PyExc_ImportError, \
        "numpy._core.multiarray failed to import" \
    ); \
    return NULL; \
  } \
}
```

changing the `NULL` to `0`:

```c
#define import_array() { \
  if (_import_array() < 0) { \
    PyErr_Print(); \
    PyErr_SetString( \
        PyExc_ImportError, \
        "numpy._core.multiarray failed to import" \
    ); \
    return 0; \
  } \
}
```

With SWIG 4.3, the `import_array` macro was included into a function that returned `void`. With SWIG 4.4, that function returns `int` (hence the GCC error above).

```python
# Not applicable
```

```shell

```

issues.title: BUG: `np.vectorize` wrapped functions are slower when keyword arguments are involved
issues.body:
### Describe the issue:

`np.vectorize` is a nice way to wrap a python function into a numpy function taking benefits of broadcasting and other boilerplate things.

However, calling a `np.vectorize` wrapped function using kwargs is lot slower than calling it without keyword arguments.

This is because numpy internally creates a [wrapper function](https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/06f38aead4c3d136522a8968a10f1f87d530863e/numpy/lib/_function_base_impl.py#L2502) that has redundant sanitization steps in every call to the function. Consider a simple example below where calling it using keyword arguments is ~5x slower!

### Reproduce the code example:

```python
>>> def func(a, b):
...     return a + b

>>> %time _ = np.vectorize(func)(np.arange(10**7), 1)
CPU times: user 540 ms, sys: 74.3 ms, total: 614 ms
Wall time: 613 ms

>>> %time _ = np.vectorize(func)(np.arange(10**7), b=1) # ~5x slower!
CPU times: user 3.31 s, sys: 64.4 ms, total: 3.38 s
Wall time: 3.38 s
```

```shell

```

```

issues.title: BUG: np.unique: return_index does not reflect the first occurrence for complex arrays with NaN
issues.body:
### Describe the issue:

### What is expected (according to documentation)

`np.unique` does not always satisfy the documented behaviour for `return_index=True` when dealing with complex numbers containing NaN values in either real or imaginary parts.

According to the documentation of np.unique, the second returned array (unique_indices) should contain the indices of _the first occurrence_ of each unique value in the original array:

> â€œthe indices of the input array that give the unique valuesâ€
> (only provided if return_index is True)

### What actually happens

In the example below:
- The array a is: [1.+1.j, nan+0.j, 0.+nan j, 1.+nan j] (with np.nan and complex numbers containing NaN).
- When equal_nan=True, the nan (or NaN-containing complex) values are considered equal according to doc.
- However, the returned unique_indices array is [0, 2]:
  - Index 0 corresponds to 1.+1.j (fine).
  - Index 2 corresponds to complex(0.0, np.nan) rather than np.nan at index 1, which appears first in the input list among the NaN-related values.

Hence, for the NaNâ€containing entries, the returned index does not reflect the earliest occurrence in the input.

### Reproduce the code example:

```python
import numpy as np

a = [1.+1.j, np.nan, complex(0.0, np.nan), complex(1.0, np.nan)]
print(np.unique(a, return_index=True, equal_nan=True))
```

### Error message:

```shell
(array([1. +1.j, 0.+nanj]), array([0, 2]))
```

This should be
```shell
(array([1. +1.j, nan+0.j]), array([0, 1]))
```

### Python and NumPy Versions:

2.4.0.dev0+git20251030.cfda63d
3.13.7 (main, Aug 14 2025, 11:12:11) [Clang 17.0.0 (clang-1700.0.13.3)]

### Runtime Environment:

[{'numpy_version': '2.4.0.dev0+git20251030.cfda63d',

issues.title: HUH: ``squeeze``ing scalars
issues.body:
I wasn't sure if this should be an "ENH", "BUG", "TYP", "DEP", or "MAINT", so I opted for the sound that came out of my mouth when I first encountered this. Feel free to change it to one of those if you feel like it.

---

This just made me "huh" out loud:

```pycon
>>> np.squeeze(1)
array(1)
>>> np.squeeze(np.array(1))
array(1)
>>> np.squeeze(np.int_(1))
np.int64(1)
```

So "scalar-likes" are not treated equally; some return numpy scalars, others return 0d arrays.

Besides this increasing the ever so important "huh/sec" rate [^1], it's also pretty annoying to express in the stubs. But before you panick and/or call the press, [the `squeeze` stubs](https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/d8eb2256ee4f21c90e8498c6008e08c960b3d174/numpy/_core/fromnumeric.pyi#L497) aren't incorrect [^3] [^2], so it's not *that* big of a disaster.

Anyway, given the array-api's lack of scalar-types, and them being infuriatingly annoying for static typing, I   think that I'm slightly leaning towards choosing 0d-arrays over scalars here. I.e., changing `squeeze` so that it always returns an instance of `numpy.ndarray` (or a <sub>sub</sub>type thereof), even if you pass it a `np.generic` scalar-type thingy. 

This would technically be a backwards-incompatible breaking change. But, considering that 0d arrays are mostly duck-type compatible, and that I don't see why anyone would want to squeeze their scalars in the first place, I doubt that many will be bothered by this change.

[^1]: Is that a thing? Well, if it isn't; then I think it should.
[^2]: they're technically not *correct* either, seeing as it *can* return `Any`
[^3]: which, given the lack of comment about it, might just have been a "happy little accident" (ðŸŽ¨)

---

**TLDR;** Let's have `numpy.squeeze` always return an array

issues.title: TYP: typing issue with `np.object_` dtype iteration
issues.body:
### Describe the issue:

`np.ndarray.__iter__` type does not correctly type the return value when `dtype` is a union containing `np.object_`

### Reproduce the code example:

```python
## The iterated value is correctly typed with unions.

import numpy as np
from typing import Any, reveal_type


def str_union(a: np.ndarray[tuple[Any], np.dtype[np.int8 | np.str_]]) -> str:
    for i in a:
        reveal_type(i)
        if isinstance(i, str):
            return i
    return "a"


kk.py:7: note: Revealed type is "numpy.signedinteger[numpy._typing._nbit_base._8Bit] | numpy.str_"



## The iterated value is correctly typed to `Any` with np.object_.

import numpy as np
from typing import Any, reveal_type

def object(a: np.ndarray[tuple[Any], np.dtype[np.object_]]) -> np.ndarray:
    for i in a:
        reveal_type(i)
        if isinstance(i, np.ndarray):
            return i
    return a


kk.py:15: note: Revealed type is "Any"


## The iterated value is incorrectly typed to `int8 | np.object_` with `np.object_` union.
It should be typed to `Any` or `int8 | Any`.

def object_union(a: np.ndarray[tuple[Any], np.dtype[np.int8 | np.object_]]) -> np.ndarray:
    for i in a:
        reveal_type(i)
        if isinstance(i, np.ndarray):
            return i
    return a


kk.py:23: note: Revealed type is "numpy.signedinteger[numpy._typing._nbit_base._8Bit] | numpy.object_"
```

### Error message:

```shell
kk.py:24: error: Subclass of "object_" and "ndarray[Any, Any]" cannot exist: "object_" is final  [unreachable]
            if isinstance(i, np.ndarray):
                          ^

[unreachable]
            if isinstance(i, np.ndarray):
                          ^

                return i

```

issues.title: BUG: Missing signatures for ufuncs
issues.body:
### Describe the issue:

Numpy ufuncs do not have valid signatures.

### Reproduce the code example:

import numpy as np
import inspect

inspect.signature(np.ufunc.accumulate)

-> 2468     return _signature_from_builtin(sigcls, obj,

File ~/miniconda3/lib/python3.10/inspect.py:2275, in _signature_from_builtin(cls, func, skip_bound_arg)
   2273 s = getattr(func, "__text_signature__", None)

-> 2275     raise ValueError("no signature found for builtin {!r}".format(func))
   2277 return _signature_fromstr(cls, func, s, skip_bound_arg)

ValueError: no signature found for builtin <method 'accumulate' of 'numpy.ufunc' objects>

2.2.6
3.10.12 | packaged by conda-forge | (main, Jun 23 2023, 22:41:52) [Clang 15.0.7 ]

### Runtime Environment:

_No response_

### Context for the issue:

In Dask we fixed a bug where `dask.array.cumprod` wasn't passing the dtype down to the underlying function calls. To do this we inspect the funcs passed in for a dtype kwarg, and if set to use a `partial` to pass the dtype on.

When used with numpy ufuncs we are now seeing exceptions because the methods do not have valid signatures so we can't check if they have a dtype kwarg. See https://github.com/dask/dask/issues/12117

We could special case this in Dask as all ufuncs have a dtype kwarg, but it would be better if we could inspect them to discover this at runtime.

#23993 is related

issues.title: How to disable BLAS/LAPACK when building Numpy v2.3+
issues.body:
The latest [numpy doc](https://numpy.org/doc/stable/building/blas_lapack.html) no longer includes instructions for disabling accelerated libraries, which were previously available. 

BLAS libraries can be an unnecessary burden for projects that depend on numpy but don't require matrix computation. In this case, they increase the package size without any functional benefits.

I tried to patch the `numpy/meson.build` by explicitly disabling blas related variables:

```
blas = disabler()
have_blas = false
...
```

However, numpy still manages to detect and link against BLAS somehow:

issues.title: BUG: Binary Builds Deadlock due to OpenBLAS threading issue with fork
issues.body:
### Describe the issue:

Consider the snippet shown below.

On my system with `numpy` installed via pip this deadlocks with GDB showing an issue in the embedded OpenBLAS where it is stuck on a mutex.  Rerunning with `export OMP_NUM_THREADS=1` resolves the issue.  I suspect this is due to a recent change in how the binary distributions are prepared (maybe previously they were not using multithreaded OpenBLAS?) . The above snippet *should* be fine, however, as it is the parent which is continuing to use NumPy and its threads should not have changed.  Maybe OpenBLAS has a bad atfork handler?

If this is intended behaviour (NumPy not being compatible with any scripts which explicitly call fork) then it might be worth using `os.register_at_fork` to ensure an exception is thrown.  

### Reproduce the code example:

```python
import numpy as np
import os

# Do some algebra
A = np.random.randn(216, 216)
np.linalg.inv(A)

# Fork but have the child do nothing
if (pid := os.fork()) != 0:
    # Deadlock!
    np.linalg.inv(A)

    # Wait for the child
    os.waitpid(pid, 0)
```

issues.title: BUG: Running test suite in parallel causes ThreadSanitizer data races
issues.body:
### Describe the issue:

When running the test suite under [pytest-run-parallel](github.com/Quansight-Labs/pytest-run-parallel) and [ThreadSanitizer](https://clang.llvm.org/docs/ThreadSanitizer.html), many tests cause data races. The affected tests (~80 test) are listed in [this spreadsheet](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1iJHNqrcPAP3GJM0oooZuv7-YI9SAE7Db-U0ZIzFzMw8/edit?usp=sharing). Below are some tests I thought were notable.

#### Tests cause a crash, with no output (some of these overlap with [ASan errors I found previously](https://github.com/numpy/numpy/issues/29890), and likely have to do with the tests crashing due to memory issues):
- [ ] numpy/_core/tests/test_arrayprint.py::test_multithreaded_array_printing
- [ ] numpy/_core/tests/test_multiarray.py::TestCreation::test_zeros_big
- [ ] numpy/_core/tests/test_regression.py::TestRegression::test_to_ctypes
- [ ] numpy/_core/tests/test_shape_base.py::TestConcatenate::test_huge_list_error

#### Segmentation fault after data race
- [ ] numpy/_core/tests/test_custom_dtypes.py::TestSFloat::test_wrapped_and_wrapped_reductions

#### RandomState data race (may be a linux-only bug)
- [ ] numpy/linalg/tests/test_linalg.py::TestCond::test_stacked_singular
- [ ] numpy/_core/tests/test_umath.py::TestLog::test_log_strides
- [ ] numpy/linalg/tests/test_linalg.py::TestCond::test_stacked_singular

#### dec_addstatus data races

- [ ] numpy/lib/tests/test_function_base.py::TestAverage::test_object_dtype
- [ ] numpy/lib/tests/test_function_base.py::TestAverage::test_object_no_weights

#### Caused test failure
- [ ] numpy/lib/tests/test_io.py::TestSaveTxt::test_large_zip
- [ ] numpy/testing/tests/test_utils.py::TestAssertNoGcCycles::test_asserts


### Steps to reproduce
- Use Python `3.14t` with ThreadSanitizer enabled.
   - Steps on how to do this can be found [here](https://py-free-threading.github.io/thread_sanitizer/). 
   - Currently using these TSAN options `export TSAN_OPTIONS=suppressions=/numpy_suppressions.txt:allocator_may_return_null=1:halt_on_error=0`
   - Using the suppression file from [here](https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/main/tools/ci/tsan_suppressions.txt)
- Build NumPy using clang, ThreadSanitizer and without openBLAS
  - `spin build --clean -- -Db_sanitize=thread -Dbuildtype=debugoptimized -Dallow-noblas=true`
- Run test suite under `pytest-run-parallel`
  - `spin test -p auto -sv`

### Error message:


I have the traceback files for all TSan warnings I ran into. Don't want to post them all here and make a mess, but I can provide any of them if needed.

issues.title: BUG: Slogdet divide by 0 runtime warning in accelerate
issues.body:
### Describe the issue:

Hi, 

In my development environment for I'm getting a divide by 0 warning that causes a test failure in the test harness when executing tests on the multivariate normal distribution.

Details:

Sequoia version 15.6
```python
import numpy as np
np.version.full_version
# '2.3.4'
np.version.git_revision
# '1458b9e79d1a5755eae9adcb346758f449b6b430'
import platform
platform.machine()
# 'arm64'
```

We've narrowed the error down to numpy and this seems to reproduce the warning from numpy. 

The example is extracted from the test case in the scipy test harness to use only the numpy parts to exhibit the divide by zero warning. Details in the rest of the web form.



### Reproduce the code example:

```python
import numpy as np

large_total_log = 1000.0
npos = 100
nzero = 2
large_entry = np.exp(large_total_log / npos)
n = npos + nzero
cov = np.zeros((n, n), dtype=float)
np.fill_diagonal(cov, large_entry)
cov[-nzero:, -nzero:] = 0

# raises a runtime warning 
np.linalg.slogdet(cov[:npos, :npos])
```

### Error message:

```shell
/Users/rlucas7/workspace/scipy-dev/env/lib/python3.13/site-packages/numpy/linalg/_linalg.py:2374: RuntimeWarning: divide by zero encountered in slogdet
  sign, logdet = _umath_linalg.slogdet(a, signature=signature)
/Users/rlucas7/workspace/scipy-dev/env/lib/python3.13/site-packages/numpy/linalg/_linalg.py:2374: RuntimeWarning: overflow encountered in slogdet
  sign, logdet = _umath_linalg.slogdet(a, signature=signature)
/Users/rlucas7/workspace/scipy-dev/env/lib/python3.13/site-packages/numpy/linalg/_linalg.py:2374: RuntimeWarning: invalid value encountered in slogdet
  sign, logdet = _umath_linalg.slogdet(a, signature=signature)
SlogdetResult(sign=np.float64(1.0), logabsdet=np.float64(1000.0))
per @rgommers cross-ref -> https://github.com/numpy/numpy/issues/29820 perhaps the same root cause in accelarate
```

### Python and NumPy Versions:

Python 3.13.7 
Numpy 2.3.4

issues.title: ENH: add atol and rtol to np.unique to allow meaningful comparison of floating types
issues.body:
### Proposed new feature or change:

Similar to np.isclose, np.unique should accept an atol and rtol parameter to allow meaningful comparisons of floating values. Currently, two floating values that are off by a single machine epsilon are considered unique which is not necessarily useful behavior. Allowing both atol and rtol allows the caller to determine what threshold is meaningful for their use case. Default values of 0 for atol and rtol seem reasonable to keep the current behavior as the default.

issues.title: BUG: weighted quantile returns incorrect result when reducing over multiple axes
issues.body:
### Describe the issue:

As stated in the title, if you provide `weights` and for instance `axis=(0, 1)` to `np.quantile` it won't return the correct result. I think it will ignore all weights except `weights[..., 0, :]` or something like this.

This happens because the internal  function `_ureduce` reshapes and merges dimensions of `a` without doing the same thing for `weights` (I'm surprised this doesn't cause index errors downstream...). See [this section](https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/main/numpy/lib/_function_base_impl.py#L3838-L3848) of `_ureduce` to understand more precisely what I mean.

This doesn't concern `np.nanquantile` (as shown below), because `nanquantile` implements its own reduction in some sense (which is also buggy, see https://github.com/numpy/numpy/issues/29709)

### Reproduce the code example:

```python
import numpy as np

a = np.array([
    [0., 0.],
    [1., 1.]
])

w = np.array([
    [1, 1],
    [1e10, 1e10]
])

# you expect all those calls to be equivalent and return 1. but the two first return 0.
print(
    np.quantile(a, 0.5, axis=(1, 0), weights=w, method='inverted_cdf'),
    np.quantile(a, 0.5, axis=(0, 1), weights=w, method='inverted_cdf'),
    np.quantile(a, 0.5, axis=None, weights=w, method='inverted_cdf')
)

print(
    np.nanquantile(a, 0.5, axis=(1, 0), weights=w, method='inverted_cdf'),
    np.nanquantile(a, 0.5, axis=(0, 1), weights=w, method='inverted_cdf'),
    np.nanquantile(a, 0.5, axis=None, weights=w, method='inverted_cdf')
)
```

issues.title: BUG: Data pointer is unaligned for empty arrays after pickle roundtrip
issues.body:
### Describe the issue:

On Linux x86-64 Python 3.14.0 (installed from `uv python`, but I haven't tested other Python installations), I find that round-tripping an empty array through `pickle` is causing it to come back with a pointer that's unaligned.

### Reproduce the code example:

```python
import numpy
import pickle

empty = numpy.zeros((0,), dtype='u4')
assert empty.ctypes.data % 4 == 0  # Passes.
roundtrip = pickle.loads(pickle.dumps(empty))
print(f"{roundtrip.ctypes.data:#x}")
assert roundtrip.flags["ALIGNED"]  # Passes.
assert roundtrip.ctypes.data % 4 == 0  # Typically fails.
```

### Error message:

The roundtripped pointer came back as (e.g.) `0x17fd2a1`, and then the final assertion fails.

### Python and NumPy Versions:

Python: 3.14.0 from `uv`
Numpy: 2.3.4 (just `pip install`)

### Runtime Environment:
```

A relatively minor problem for me: when interoperating with Rust, this causes us to need extra care before taking out Rust slices, because Rust slices require their backing pointer to be non-null and aligned, even for an empty slice.

issues.title: ENH: `tobytes` operation is slow when data is not contiguous
issues.body:
### Proposed new feature or change:

Hi, 

I noticed that for large array sizes, `tobytes` operation took much more time if the data is not contiguous. But if the array is explicitly made contiguous, the time taken was little less. The effect is more significant when the array is bigger. 

Here's a code snippet showing the same. 

```python 

import numpy as np 
import time 
contiguous_img = np.random.randn(3,224,224 )
non_contiguous_img = np.random.randn(3,224,224 ).transpose(1,2,0)


assert np.ascontiguousarray(non_contiguous_img).tobytes() == non_contiguous_img.tobytes()

tick = time.time()
for i in range(1000):
    contiguous_img.tobytes()
tock = time.time() 

print(f"To convert Contiguous image it took : {tock - tick}")


tick = time.time()
for i in range(1000):
    non_contiguous_img.tobytes()
tock = time.time() 

print(f"To convert non Contiguous image it took : {tock - tick}")


tick = time.time()
for i in range(1000):
    np.ascontiguousarray(non_contiguous_img).tobytes()
tock = time.time()


print(f"[optimised] To convert non Contiguous image it took : {tock - tick}")

````
And it gave, 

```bash 
>>> 
To convert Contiguous image it took : 0.04578709602355957
To convert non Contiguous image it took : 0.7183928489685059
[optimised] To convert non Contiguous image it took : 0.34071874618530273

```  

I verified this code on google colab as well and it gave me similar results which means its not just my device specific thing. (Im using jetson Orin) . But when the array is small, the time taken is almost same. Sometimes direct calling `tobytes` for non-contiguous array takes less time, sometimes calling `ascontiguous` and then `tobytes` takes less time.

Maybe, just maybe calling ascontiguous will give us some speedup is my hypothesis. Thats why i created this issue to get initial feedback from maintainers and the community. 

Thanks

issues.title: ENH: Replace nan-ignoring functions with an ignore_nan flag to their normal counterparts
issues.body:
### Proposed new feature or change:

[Mailing list post](https://mail.python.org/archives/list/numpy-discussion@python.org/thread/P4EEL5P2PNDASWLI24CPHOW2KG2LZ3YY/)

NumPy has the following nan-ignoring functions:

[Mathematical functions](https://numpy.org/doc/stable/reference/routines.math.html):

- [nanprod](https://numpy.org/doc/stable/reference/generated/numpy.nanprod.html)
- [nansum](https://numpy.org/doc/stable/reference/generated/numpy.nansum.html)
- [nancumprod](https://numpy.org/doc/stable/reference/generated/numpy.nancumprod.html)
- [nancumsum](https://numpy.org/doc/stable/reference/generated/numpy.nancumsum.html)
- [nanmax](https://numpy.org/doc/stable/reference/generated/numpy.nanmax.html)
- [nanmin](https://numpy.org/doc/stable/reference/generated/numpy.nanmin.html)

[Sorting, searching, and counting](https://numpy.org/doc/stable/reference/routines.sort.html):

- [nanargmax](https://numpy.org/doc/stable/reference/generated/numpy.nanargmax.html)
- [nanargmin](https://numpy.org/doc/stable/reference/generated/numpy.nanargmin.html)

[Statistics](https://numpy.org/doc/stable/reference/routines.statistics.html):

- [nanpercentile](https://numpy.org/doc/stable/reference/generated/numpy.nanpercentile.html)
- [nanquantile](https://numpy.org/doc/stable/reference/generated/numpy.nanquantile.html)
- [nanmedian](https://numpy.org/doc/stable/reference/generated/numpy.nanmedian.html)
- [nanmean](https://numpy.org/doc/stable/reference/generated/numpy.nanmean.html)
- [nanstd](https://numpy.org/doc/stable/reference/generated/numpy.nanstd.html)
- [nanvar](https://numpy.org/doc/stable/reference/generated/numpy.nanvar.html)

**Suggestion**: Replace these functions with an `ignore_nan` flag to their normal counterparts.

Advantages:

- Avoids creating and maintaining two separate versions of each function.
- More user-friendly: It's simpler and easier to toggle a boolean flag.

This has been briefly suggested before:

- https://mail.python.org/archives/list/numpy-discussion@python.org/message/FQ362NGJLOJFN3BCJVST5TAQZCVWZTNO/
- https://github.com/numpy/numpy/pull/25474#issuecomment-1868484678

Precedents:

- [pandas](https://pandas.pydata.org/docs/) has a `skipna` argument for [reductions](https://pandas.pydata.org/docs/reference/api/pandas.api.extensions.ExtensionArray._reduce.html) and [accumulations](https://pandas.pydata.org/docs/reference/api/pandas.api.extensions.ExtensionArray._accumulate.html).
- [scipy](https://docs.scipy.org/doc/scipy/dev/api-dev/nan_policy.html) has a `nan_policy` argument.

issues.title: BUG: MaskedArray.mean (and sum) do not propagate subclass metadata via _update_from, unlike var/std
issues.body:
### Describe the issue:

When subclassing numpy.ma.MaskedArray, user-defined metadata stored in `_optinfo` (or propagated through `_update_from`) is not preserved by `mean()` and `sum()` when a mask is present.
In contrast, operations such as `std()` and `var()` do preserve this metadata, resulting in inconsistent behavior across reduction methods.

This asymmetry appears to arise because the masked branches of `mean()` and `sum()` do not call `_update_from(self)` on their return values, while `var()` and `std()` do.

This affects all subclasses that rely on `_optinfo` (the official mechanism for propagating arbitrary metadata in `MaskedArray`).

## Expected behavior

All `MaskedArray` reduction operations that return masked-array results should preserve subclass metadata consistently â€” either by calling `_update_from(self)` or otherwise copying `_optinfo`.

That is, the result of mean() (and sum()) should have the same _optinfo content as std() and var() do.

### Reproduce the code example:

```python
import numpy as np
import numpy.ma as ma

class RealisticInfoArray(ma.MaskedArray):
    def __new__(cls, data, mask=ma.nomask, info=None, **kwargs):
        obj = ma.MaskedArray(data, mask=mask, **kwargs).view(cls)
        if info is not None:
            obj._optinfo['info'] = info
        return obj

    def __array_finalize__(self, obj):
        super().__array_finalize__(obj)

    @property
    def info(self):
        return self._optinfo.get('info', None)

    @info.setter
    def info(self, value):
        self._optinfo['info'] = value

arr = np.arange(6).reshape(2, 3)
mask = [[0, 1, 0],
        [0, 0, 1]]

x = RealisticInfoArray(arr, mask=mask, info="metadata")

print("Original info:", x.info) # prints: "metadata"

# Example 1 â€” mean() loses metadata
m = x.mean(axis=-1)
print("mean info:", m.info) # prints: None

# Example 2 â€” std() preserves metadata
s = x.std(axis=-1)
print("std info:", s.info) # prints: "metadata"
```

### Error message:

```shell

```

### Python and NumPy Versions:

2.0.0
3.12.2 (main, Apr 30 2024, 12:31:32) [Clang 15.0.0 (clang-1500.3.9.4)]

### Runtime Environment:

_No response_

### Context for the issue:

This issue breaks subclassing of `MaskedArray` for any class that stores custom metadata (e.g., provenance info, data source identifiers, processing flags, etc.).
The loss of `_optinfo` during `mean()` makes subclass behavior unpredictable depending on which reduction operation is called.

issues.title: STY: Propose refactoring `str.format()` to f-strings where applicable
issues.body:
## Description
Several string formatting and `print()` statements in the codebase still use the older `.format()` method. Since Python 3.6+, f-strings provide a more readable, concise, and efficient way to format strings. This issue proposes refactoring `.format()` calls to f-strings wherever appropriate, without changing the behavior of the code.

## Why This Change?
- Enhances code readability and maintainability
- Aligns with modern Python best practices
- Reduces the likelihood of formatting errors
- Slightly improves performance for string operations
## Example
**Current**:
```python 
print("Sum of {} and {} is {}".format(a, b, a+b))
```
**Proposed**
```python 
print(f"Sum of {a} and {b} is {a + b}")
```
## Help and Feedback
I am a new contributor and eager to learn. I would greatly appreciate any guidance or feedback on this refactoring. If this issue is not appropriate, I would be thankful for any advice on how to proceed. Looking forward to learning and contributing to the NumPy community!

issues.title: BUG: truediv with object array and timedelta64 raises
issues.body:
### Describe the issue:

Dividing a NumPy array of object dtype holding Python timedeltas by `np.timedelta64` raises an exception, where as dividing elementwise is successful. I would have expected the op to act elementwise successfully.

### Reproduce the code example:

```python
from datetime import timedelta
import numpy as np

arr = np.array([timedelta(seconds=1)], dtype="object")
scalar = np.timedelta64(1, 's')

print(arr[0] / scalar)
# 1.0

print(arr / 2)
# [datetime.timedelta(microseconds=500000)]

print(arr / scalar)
# numpy._core._exceptions._UFuncBinaryResolutionError: ufunc 'divide' cannot use operands with types dtype('O') and dtype('<m8[s]')
```

### Error message:

```shell

```

### Python and NumPy Versions:

Python 3.11.13
numpy 2.3.4

### Runtime Environment:

_No response_

### Context for the issue:

Encountered in https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/issues/62712

cc @seberg

issues.title: DOC: Confusing advanced indexing when mixing tuple, integer, and range
issues.body:
### Issue with current documentation:

When addressing a 3+ dim array with a tuple in its 3rd or later dims, the returned shape depends on the order of previous ranges/integers:

    >>> k = np.ones((4,5,6),)
    >>> k[:,0,(1,2)].shape
    (4, 2) #expected
    >>> k[0,:,(1,2)].shape
    (2, 5) #unexpected! actually transpose of right answer
    >>> k[0,:,:][:,(1,2)].shape
    (5, 2) #workaround
    >>> k[:1,:,(1,2)].shape
    (1, 5, 2) #workaround 

This *might* be an actual bug. It seems the actually unexpected case should be canonically correct: zero getting broadcast to (0,0). The documentation is unclear as to how this situation should behave, the example in that case uses unclear variable names:

    result[i_1, ..., i_M] == x[ind_1[i_1, ..., i_M], ind_2[i_1, ..., i_M],
                           ..., ind_N[i_1, ..., i_M]]

from here:
https://numpy.org/doc/stable/user/basics.indexing.html#integer-array-indexing


### Idea or request for content:

The priority between ranges and tuples seems to be undefined and I don't know what it *should* be. If the described behavior is expected, the documentation should describe behavior when mixing with ranges better.

issues.title: ENH: Add function to compute the mode of integer parts of floating-point arrays
issues.body:
Description

Currently, numpy provides np.mean, np.median, and np.std, among other descriptive statistics.
However, it lacks a convenient way to compute the mode of the integer parts of an array containing floating-point numbers.

For example, given:

import numpy as np

data = np.array([1.2, 1.7, 2.3, 2.9, 3.1, 3.6, 3.7, 3.9])


A function like np.mode_intpart(data) could return 3,
because the integer part 3 appears most frequently when truncating or flooring the values.

Currently, to achieve this, users must manually perform:

ints = np.floor(data).astype(int)
mode_value = np.bincount(ints).argmax()


This workaround is not immediately intuitive for beginners and feels inconsistent with the convenience of other NumPy descriptive statistics functions.

Proposed solution

Add a function such as:

np.mode_intpart(data, method='floor')


where the method argument could optionally specify 'floor', 'ceil', or 'trunc' for different rounding behaviors.

Benefit

Simplifies exploratory data analysis involving mixed continuous/discrete datasets.

Helps beginners in statistics and Python understand modes without complex workarounds.

Keeps API consistency with other NumPy descriptive stats.

Example
import numpy as np

data = np.array([1.2, 1.7, 2.3, 2.9, 3.1, 3.6, 3.7, 3.9])
np.mode_intpart(data)
# Expected output: 3

Related discussions

There are frequent StackOverflow and forum questions about computing the mode of floats or the mode of integer parts.
A built-in function would be educational and practical.

Proposed by Leandro (Argentina) â€” data enthusiast learning Python and statistics.

issues.title: TYP: Type hint for np.random.Generator.shuffle is wrong
issues.body:
### Describe the issue:

The type hint for np.random.Generator.shuffle is ArrayLike ([here](https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/a1467b5e35bc345fcb6204512e827d0d6a36d4f8/numpy/random/_generator.pyi#L853)), but the documentation says it takes a ndarray or MutableSequence. There are a few differences e.g.:
- A `list[object]` is a MutableSequence but not ArrayLike
- A `complex` is ArrayLike but not an ndarray nor MutableSequence (passing it crashes at runtime because it doesn't support `len`)

This looks similar to #19507, but that was claiming a type-check error when passing `list[int]` (which does actually work, because it is ArrayLike) and was found to be due to PyCharm getting type annotations from some external source.

### Reproduce the code example:

```python
import numpy as np

rng = np.random.default_rng()
lst = [object(), object()]
rng.shuffle(lst)
rng.shuffle(1 + 2j)
```

### Error message:

```shell
shuffle_type.py:5: error: Argument 1 to "shuffle" of "Generator" has incompatible type "list[object]"; expected "Buffer | _SupportsArray[dtype[Any]] | _NestedSequence[_SupportsArray[dtype[Any]]] | complex | bytes | str | _NestedSequence[complex | bytes | str]"  [arg-type]
Found 1 error in 1 file (checked 1 source file)


It should instead be complaining about like 6, where 1 + 2j is not valid for shuffle.
```

### Python and NumPy Versions:

2.3.4
3.12.3 (main, Aug 14 2025, 17:47:21) [GCC 13.3.0]

### Type-checker version and settings:

mypy 1.14.1

No command-line options beyond the filename, and no config file.

### Additional typing packages.

_No response_

I'm working on making the NumPy test suite more thread safe by running it under [pytest-run-parallel](github.com/Quansight-Labs/pytest-run-parallel) (more info here #29552). When running `test_subarray`, `test_structure_aligned`, and `test_padded_union`, which are located at `numpy/tests/test_ctypeslib.py::TestAsCtypesType`, they give AssertionErrors when ran in parallel threads.

issues.title: BUG: Importing `numpy.distutils.msvccompiler` fails when using the latest Python 3.11 (Python 3.11.14)
issues.body:
### Describe the issue:

In the recent release Python 3.11.14 (Oct 9 2025), the version of setuptools is upgraded. (see https://github.com/python/cpython/pull/135396 )

Due to this change, CI tests running on Python 3.11 is currently failing. 
Example: https://github.com/numpy/numpy/actions/runs/18397458439/job/52421553249


According to the documentation ( https://numpy.org/devdocs/reference/distutils_status_migration.html#numpy-setuptools-interaction ) , there seem to be two possible solutions:


* 1: Completely erase `numpy.distutils`

  * The document states that "[numpy.distutils](https://numpy.org/devdocs/reference/distutils.html#module-numpy.distutils) has been deprecated in NumPy 1.23.0. It will be removed for Python 3.12; for Python <= 3.11 it will not be removed until 2 years after the Python 3.12 release (Oct 2025).".
So, this seems to be a good time to remove it completely.


* 2: set `setuptools<60.0` when running CI tests on Python 3.11

  * This workaround would avoid incompatibility between `numpy.distutils` and recent `setuptools` versions.

In my opinion, option 1  seems more appropriate in the long term, but I will follow
the maintainersâ€™ suggestion.


### Reproduce the code example:

```python
spin test -- numpy/tests/test_public_api.py::test_api_importable
```

issues.title: ENH: Add tests for linalg.getattr deprecation mechanism
issues.body:
### Enhancement Proposal: Tests for `linalg.__getattr__` Deprecation

**Description**:
The `__getattr__` hook in `numpy/linalg/linalg.py` (around line 10) forwards attributes from the private `_linalg` module while issuing a `DeprecationWarning` to guide users to the public API. This is great for backward compatibility, but it currently lacks dedicated tests in `numpy/linalg/tests/test_linalg.py` for key behaviors like:
- Successful attribute forwarding (e.g., `inv`, `det`) with correct warning emission.
- Raising `AttributeError` for missing attributes.
- Accurate `stacklevel=3` in warnings for proper traceback pointing.

Adding these would ensure reliability, especially for ML workflows relying on linalg (e.g., SVD in data augmentation or solving in regression, as in my projects using NumPy with TensorFlow/scikit-learn).

**Proposed Changes**:
- Add a new test class `TestLinalgGetattrDeprecation` with pytest functions:
  - `test_getattr_successful`: Captures warning and asserts array equality (e.g., for `inv` on a sample matrix).
  - `test_getattr_missing`: Asserts `AttributeError` for non-existent attr like `foo`.
  - `test_getattr_stacklevel`: Verifies warning frame points to caller.
- Use `warnings.catch_warnings` and `numpy.testing.assert_array_equal` for assertions.
- Aim for 100% coverage of the `__getattr__` logic.

**Minimal Repro/Expected Behavior**:
Here's a snippet demonstrating the current behavior (tested on NumPy 2.1.0, Python 3.12):

```python
import numpy as np
import warnings

# Successful access
with warnings.catch_warnings(record=True) as w:
    warnings.simplefilter("always")
    A = np.array([[1, 2], [3, 4]], dtype=float)
    result = np.linalg.linalg.inv(A)  # Triggers warning
    expected = np.linalg.inv(A)
    # Assert result == expected and warning emitted
print("Warning emitted:", len(w) == 1)
print("Warning message:", str(w[0].message) if w else "No warning")

# Missing attr
try:
    _ = np.linalg.linalg.foo
except AttributeError as e:
    print("Error:", str(e))

issues.title: BUG: Running test suite in parallel with AddressSanitizer results in errors and crashes

labels.name: 39 - free-threading
labels.description: PRs and issues related to support for free-threading CPython (a.k.a. no-GIL, PEP 703)

issues.body:
### Describe the issue:

When running the NumPy test suite with [pytest-run-parallel](https://github.com/Quansight-Labs/pytest-run-parallel) and [AddressSanitizer](https://clang.llvm.org/docs/AddressSanitizer.html), some tests result in ASan errors and a few even result in fatal terminations that crash the entire terminal.

### Affected tests
- `numpy/_core/tests/test_arrayprint.py::test_multithreaded_array_printing`
  - Fatal termination, no output or specific error
- `numpy/_core/tests/test_shape_base.py::TestConcatenate::test_huge_list_error`
  - Fatal termination, no output or specific error
- `numpy/_core/tests/test_array_coercion.py::TestArrayLikes::test_too_large_array_error_paths`
  - No crash, failed to allocate bytes ASan error
- `numpy/_core/tests/test_multiarray.py::TestCreation::test_malloc_fails`
  - No crash, failed to allocate bytes ASan error
- `numpy/lib/tests/test_io.py::TestFromTxt::test_utf8_file_nodtype_unicode`
  - Fatal termination after printing `heap-use-after-free on address` ASan error

### Steps to reproduce
- Use Python `3.14t-dev` with AddressSanitizer enabled.
   - Steps on how to do this can be found [here](https://py-free-threading.github.io/thread_sanitizer/) or in [this PR](https://github.com/numpy/numpy/pull/29757) for the docs. 
   - Currently using these ASAN options `export ASAN_OPTIONS=detect_leaks=0:symbolize=1:strict_init_order=true:allocator_may_return_null=1:halt_on_error=0`
- Build NumPy using clang, AddressSanitizer and without openBLAS
  - `spin build --clean -- -Db_sanitize=address -Dbuildtype=debugoptimized -Dallow-noblas=true`
- Run test suite under `pytest-run-parallel`
  - `spin test -- --parallel-threads=auto -sv`

N/A

issues.title: BUG: Thread Usage Limitation in NumPy Dot Product on Windows on ARM64 Setup
issues.body:
### Describe the issue:

I have a Windows on ARM(12 core) setup. I installed Python 3.13.7 and then installed NumPy (v2.3.0) using the command: pip install numpy.

After that, I ran a simple benchmarking script:
import numpy as np
import time
import os

N = 10000
A = np.random.rand(N, N)
B = np.random.rand(N, N)

start = time.time()
C = np.dot(A, B)
end = time.time()

I noticed that it utilizes only 4 cores, even after setting OPENBLAS_NUM_THREADS to a value greater than 4. It still uses only 4 threads. However, if I set it to a value below 4, it behaves as expected like scheduling that much thread.

I check on amd64 device as well, there it is working as expected it is using all core there, for same workload.

Any idea what could be limitation here?

issues.title: BUG: shrinking an object array with .resize does not decref the shrunk items
issues.body:
### Describe the issue:

While investigating `array.resize` in the context of #29878, I noticed that it seemed not to worry at all about the array containing references. This is fine if the array is expanded, but not if it is shrunk.

I think in principle, it is not difficult to solve, though definitely annoying, since an object can be inside a structured array too. Possibly, it makes more sense just to forbid resizing of arrays that hold references.

### Reproduce the code example:

```python
import numpy as np
import sys
import gc

a = object()
b = np.array([a, a])
sys.getrefcount(a)
# 4
b.resize(1)
gc.collect()
sys.getrefcount(a)
# 4
del b
gc.collect()
sys.getrefcount(a)
# 3  (without the resize, this correctly states 2)

issues.title: ENH: Add optional overflow warning or automatic dtype promotion in `np.sum`
issues.body:
### Proposed new feature or change:

When summing large integer arrays, `np.sum` can silently overflow depending on the dtype and system architecture.  
For example, summing an `int32` array on a 32-bit system can produce incorrect results without any warning.

### Reproduction

```python
import numpy as np

array = np.arange(10**8 + 1, dtype=np.int32)
np.sum(array)  # May overflow depending on the environment
```

On 64-bit systems (or when using `int64`), this gives the correct result, but on 32-bit systems or with `int32` arrays, it silently wraps around due to overflow.

### Proposed behavior

It would be helpful if np.sum provided one of the following features:
- Automatic dtype promotion â€” promote smaller integer types (e.g. `int32` â†’ `int64`) to avoid overflow, or
- Optional warning parameter â€” e.g. `warn_on_overflow=True`, which would raise or log a warning when overflow is detected.

This would make `np.sum` more consistent with Pythonâ€™s built-in `sum`, which automatically handles large integers, and could reduce confusion when switching between platforms.

### Motivation

While this behavior is consistent with NumPyâ€™s current design, it might be unintuitive for users who expect consistent numerical results across different architectures.
Providing a warning or an optional type promotion could make this behavior easier to understand and improve usability.

### Describe the issue:

We discovered on issue in scipy CI for the macos-15-intel image (so macOS15 on x86_64), see https://github.com/scipy/scipy/pull/23728. 

We are doing some numpy calculations with two arrays that are equal. The output from the calculations are not equal, which is causing a test to fail.

I've tried to produce a MWE here, using the numerical values from the test. We can add commits to a scipy repo if it would help fix the issue.

### Reproduce the code example:

```python
qd1 = np.array([0.08657014997765064, 0.13163636378278895, 0.2875018918897967, 0.6033886973966058,

issues.title: reconsider longdouble value of epislon?
issues.body:
Is there a semantic definition of `epsilon` that can used as a property to be tested that justifies this choice?  My understanding of `epsilon` is that it is the smallest positive value such that `1 + epsilon` is not `1`.  This is the "mainstream definition" of [*machine epsilon* according to wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_epsilon).  If that is the property that should be satisfied by `epsilon`, then `2^-1074` (i.e. 5e-324) is the correct value.

If it is desirable to avoid subnormal numbers in a double-double representation, then `epsilon` would be `2^-1022` (i.e `np.finfo(np.float64).tiny = 2.2250738585072014e-308`).

I guess the justification for `2^-105` is by analogy to regular double precision, where `epsilon` is `2^-52` (i.e. use `2^(-nbits+1)`). But is that a useful definition?

_Originally posted by @WarrenWeckesser in https://github.com/numpy/numpy/pull/29836#discussion_r2402292975_

issues.title: ENH: Add weights-parameter to numpy.ndarray.sum

labels.name: 57 - Close?
labels.description: Issues which may be closable unless discussion continued

issues.body:
### Proposed new feature or change:

Hey, I am looking for a comfortable way to compute weighted sums and while this can be done by `np.dot`,
I want to do it for ndarrays along a given axis,
i.e. I need a `weights`-parameter in `numpy.ndarray.sum` doing the same as the `weights`-parameter in `numpy.average`, so the docs for the parameter should look like

"""
weights : array_like, optional

An array of weights associated with the values in a. Each value in a contributes to the sum according to its associated weight. The array of weights must be the same shape as a if no axis is specified, otherwise the weights must have dimensions and shape consistent with a along the specified axis. If weights=None, then all data in a are assumed to have a weight equal to one. The calculation is:

`sum = sum(a * weights)`

where the sum is over all included elements.
"""

Best regards!

issues.title: TYP: `shape` field is typed `Any` instead of `tuple[int, ...]
issues.body:
### Describe the issue:

With numpy >=2.3, given a numpy-array `m`, `m.shape` field is typed `tuple[Any, ...]`, whereas, with numpy <2.3, it was typed `tuple[int, ...]`.


### Reproduce the code example:

```python
# The following code fails to type-check with `mypy --strict`:
# error: Returning Any from function declared to return "int"  [no-any-return]

import numpy as np
import numpy.typing as npt
def get_bitlength(m: npt.NDArray[np.float64]) -> int:
     return m.shape[0].bit_length()
```

### Error message:

```shell
`mypy --strict`:
error: Returning Any from function declared to return "int"  [no-any-return]
```

### Python and NumPy Versions:

Numpy 2.3.3
Python 3.13.0 | packaged by conda-forge | (main, Nov 27 2024, 19:18:26) [Clang 18.1.8 ]
mypy 1.18.2

### Runtime Environment:

[{'numpy_version': '2.3.3',
  'python': '3.13.0 | packaged by conda-forge | (main, Nov 27 2024, 19:18:26) '
            '[Clang 18.1.8 ]',
  'uname': uname_result(system='Darwin', node='MAC-02008476', release='24.6.0', version='Darwin Kernel Version 24.6.0: Mon Aug 11 21:16:52 PDT 2025; root:xnu-11417.140.69.701.11~1/RELEASE_ARM64_T8112', machine='arm64')},
 {'simd_extensions': {'baseline': ['NEON', 'NEON_FP16', 'NEON_VFPV4', 'ASIMD'],
                      'found': ['ASIMDHP'],
                      'not_found': ['ASIMDFHM']}}]

### Context for the issue:

We circumvent the bug by using a local variable:
```python
def get_bitlength(m: npt.NDArray[np.float64]) -> int:
     bitlength: int = m.shape[0].bit_length()
     return bitlength
```
We prefer using a local variable over a type cast, since `mypy` will be able to catch a type error if any.

issues.title: BUG: Reshaping error with leading singleton dimension
issues.body:
### Describe the issue:

If the first dim of an array is singleton and I select the slice after that using an index list, the resulting shape has the leading singleton dim and selected dim transposed, which can lead to broadcasting errors in certain cases.
I only tested that with numpy 1.26.4, not sure if numpy 2.X has a similar issue.

### Reproduce the code example:

```python
import numpy as np

# create array
arr = np.random.randint(10, size=(10,10,10))
# list to select indices
lst = [2, 3, 6, 7]
print(arr[:, lst, :].shape)
# should print (10, 4, 10), and it does indeed

# now consider singleton dims:
arr = np.random.randint(10, size=(10,1,10,10))
print(arr[:, :, lst, :].shape)
# should print (10, 1, 4, 10), and indeed it does
print(arr[0, :, lst, :].shape)
# should print (1, 4, 10) but does print (4, 1, 10)
```

issues.title: ENH: `np.vectorize` hides signature during jupyter introspection.
issues.body:
### Proposed new feature or change:

If I write a function in a python module or in my juptyer notebook, when I am writing to call that function in a jupyter notebook, I can press `tab` to see the function signature and docstring. This helps me quickly write code, especially if the function has many arguments. However if I have wrapped the function in `np.vectorize` I instead see documentation for the `vectorize` class. This spoils the benefits of the tab complete tooling available in jupyter and other IDE-like environments.

I would like if I could still see the docstring for my function even when it is wrapped in `np.vectorize`. I know there are tools like `functools.wraps` that can help with this sort of thing, but I also know that it can still be tricky to get the desired behavior. I wonder if this has been considered before for `np.vectorize`?

issues.title: DOC: numpy.result_type promotion "algorithm" is outdated

labels.name: sprintable
labels.description: Issue fits the time-frame and setting of a sprint

issues.body:
### Describe the issue:

According to the API Reference, the algorithm of [numpy.result_type](https://numpy.org/doc/stable/reference/generated/numpy.result_type.html#numpy.result_type) determines the output type following these steps:

1. Categories are determined by first checking which of boolean, integer (int/uint), or floating point (float/complex) the maximum kind of all the arrays and the scalars are.

2.  If there are only scalars or the maximum category of the scalars is higher than the maximum category of the arrays, the data types are combined with [promote_types](https://numpy.org/doc/stable/reference/generated/numpy.promote_types.html#numpy.promote_types) to produce the return value.

3.  Otherwise, [min_scalar_type](https://numpy.org/doc/stable/reference/generated/numpy.min_scalar_type.html#numpy.min_scalar_type) is called on each scalar, and the resulting data types are all combined with [promote_types](https://numpy.org/doc/stable/reference/generated/numpy.promote_types.html#numpy.promote_types) to produce the return value.

However, when it's provided with a Python scalar and an ndarray of the same category (e.g., int), it seems it completely ignores the scalar and outputs whatever datatype the ndarray has (and that contradicts the third point above; according to the doc, it should apply `min_scalar_type` on the scalar, and follow that with a call to `promote_types`).

However, when the provided scalar is a NumPy scalar, the behavior is different: what it seemingly does is only a call to `promote_types`

So, I'm wondering why the behavior is inconsistent on NumPy/Python scalars, and what exactly the role of `min_scalar_type` is in this context?

Please take a look at the provided code that shows this unexpected behaviour with a couple of examples.  

### Reproduce the code example:

```python
import numpy as np

#############
# Example 1 #
#############

# Both the ndarray and the scalar are of the same category (int)

s = -129
a = np.empty(1, dtype='i1')

# Python Scalar & ndarray

# The following outputs 'int8' (completely ignoring the scalar)
print(np.result_type(s, a))

# according to the doc; it should have called:
print(np.promote_types(np.min_scalar_type(s), a.dtype))  # gives int16

# NumPy Scalar & ndarray

# gives 'int16' (seemingly only calls np.promote_types)
print(np.result_type(np.int16(s), a))  
 
#############
# Example 2 #
#############

# The ndarray has a higher category (float vs int)

s = np.iinfo(np.int64).max
a = np.empty(1, np.float32)

# Python Scalar & ndarray

# The following outputs 'float32' (completely ignoring the scalar)
print(np.result_type(s, a))

# according to the doc; it should have called:
print(np.promote_types(np.min_scalar_type(s), a.dtype))  # gives float64

# NumPy Scalar & ndarray

# gives 'float64' (seemingly only calls np.promote_types)
print(np.result_type(np.int64(1), a))

# Pay attention to the following: (np.min_scalar_type is not used at all)
print(np.min_scalar_type(np.int64(1)))  # gives uint8
print(np.promote_types(np.min_scalar_type(np.int64(1)), a.dtype)) # gives float32
```

### Python and NumPy Versions:

Python:     3.11.5
NumPy:     2.3.1

issues.title: BUG: recarray, masked_array and datetime break fill value calculation
issues.body:
### Describe the issue:

I am unable to sort a masked_array of records, as the records contain timestamps, and this breaks the minimum_fill_value function.

This might either be due to the unusual wrapping of the value into an extra array that was introduced by afcc560 (see Example 1) or it might be that there is an inconsistency on array construction in when unpacking values in the np.array function (see Example 2) which is a property that afcc560 relies on.

import numpy as np
import datetime as dt

rec = np.array([(dt.date(2025,4,1),)], dtype=[('foo','<M8[D]')])
ma = np.ma.masked_array(rec)
np.sort(ma)
# Example 2
np.array((np.array("Hello"),), dtype=[('foo', '<U8')]) # This works

issues.title: TYP: Slicing a view is typed as `ndarray` instead of `Self`
issues.body:
### Describe the issue:

Slicing a view returns a view of the same class at runtime, but it is always typed as `ndarray` instead of `Self`.
https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/8020362811e0c857cc26a8e63bcfeaf9ee9885b2/numpy/__init__.pyi#L2105

As a result, the code attached to this issue fails to type-check even though there is no error at runtime. A current workaround is to replace `m3 = m2[1:2]` with `m3 = m2[1:2].view(C)`, but this should not be necessary.

### Reproduce the code example:

```python
import numpy as np

class C(np.ndarray):
    def foo(self):
        print("foo")

m = np.array([0, 1, 2])
m2 = m.view(C)
m3 = m2[1:2]
m3.foo() # succeeds; however, mypy reports that `ndarray` has no method `foo`
```

### Error message:

```shell
The code executes without any errors, but mypy reports the following type error:

test_numpy.py:13: error: "ndarray[tuple[int, ...], Any]" has no attribute "foo"  [attr-defined]
```

### Python and NumPy Versions:

Python 3.13.0 | packaged by conda-forge | (main, Nov 27 2024, 19:18:26) [Clang 18.1.8 ]
Numpy 2.2.6

### Runtime Environment:

[{'numpy_version': '2.2.6',
  'python': '3.13.0 | packaged by conda-forge | (main, Nov 27 2024, 19:18:26) '
            '[Clang 18.1.8 ]',

 {'simd_extensions': {'baseline': ['NEON', 'NEON_FP16', 'NEON_VFPV4', 'ASIMD'],
                      'found': ['ASIMDHP'],
                      'not_found': ['ASIMDFHM']}}]

This issue forces us to add unnecessary calls to the method `view` for our code to pass the `mypy` type-checker.

issues.title: BUG: unused function warnings building NumPy
issues.body:
On current `main`, I see the following warnings when I build NumPy:

```
../numpy/_core/src/multiarray/lowlevel_strided_loops.c.src:85:10: warning: unused function 'ToDoubleBits' [-Wunused-function]
   85 | uint64_t ToDoubleBits(uint16_t h)
      |          ^~~~~~~~~~~~
../numpy/_core/src/multiarray/lowlevel_strided_loops.c.src:116:12: warning: unused function '_npy_halfbits_to_doublebits' [-Wunused-function]
  116 | npy_uint64 _npy_halfbits_to_doublebits(npy_uint16 h){
      |            ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
2 warnings generated.
```

The first one is straightforward to fix, it just needs some conditional compilation to only define `ToDoubleBits` when it's actually used:

<details>

```diff

diff --git a/numpy/_core/src/multiarray/lowlevel_strided_loops.c.src b/numpy/_core/src/multiarray/lowlevel_strided_loops.c.src
index 13a126c538..38a3983887 100644
--- a/numpy/_core/src/multiarray/lowlevel_strided_loops.c.src
+++ b/numpy/_core/src/multiarray/lowlevel_strided_loops.c.src
@@ -81,6 +81,9 @@

 /* half-to-double, copied from CPP to allow inlining */

+#if !defined(NPY_HAVE_AVX512FP16) && \
+    !(defined(NPY_HAVE_VSX3) && defined(NPY_HAVE_VSX3_HALF_DOUBLE)) && \
+    !defined(__ARM_FP16_FORMAT_IEEE)
 static NPY_GCC_OPT_3
 uint64_t ToDoubleBits(uint16_t h)
 {
@@ -111,6 +114,7 @@ uint64_t ToDoubleBits(uint16_t h)
             return d_sgn + (((uint64_t)(h&0x7fffu) + 0xfc000u) << 42);
     }
 }
+#endif

 NPY_FINLINE
 npy_uint64 _npy_halfbits_to_doublebits(npy_uint16 h){


```

</details>

but I'm stumped on fixing the second one, because it's used a few levels of indirection deep inside some macros used in templated functions.

Ping @mattip, I'm pretty sure these new warnings were introduced by #29129.

issues.title: Float32 issues in mean of large array with non-singleton inner dimension
issues.body:
### Describe the issue:

Let

```python
rng = np.random.default_rng(802701)
X = rng.uniform(low=250, high=320, size=(32 * 32 * 32 * 320, 2)).astype(np.float32)
```

Then `X.mean(axis=0)` differs quite a bit (6% error) from `X.astype(np.float64).mean(axis=0)`. This behavior depends on shape and overall size.

I tried a few things and (referencing the code below)

Big errors if
* `axis = (0,)`, and `X.size[1] > 1`

Small errors (expected with `float32`) if
* `axis = (0, 1)` or `X.size[1] == 1`
* `size = (32 * 32 * 320, 2)`  (32 times smaller)
* `size = (2 * 32 * 32 * 320, 1)`  (same size, but inner dimension is 1)


### Reproduce the code example:

```python
import numpy as np

rng = np.random.default_rng(802701)
axis = (0,)
X = rng.uniform(low=250, high=320, size=(32 * 32 * 32 * 320, 2)).astype(np.float32)
m32 = X.mean(axis=axis)
m64 = X.astype(np.float64).mean(axis=axis)
print(f"Relative Diff={(m32 - m64) / m64}")
print(f"Diff={m32 - m64}")
```

### Error message:

```shell

```

### Python and NumPy Versions:

issues.title: BUG: `pcg_output_cm_128_64` is not defined for emulated 128-bit math case: `warning: inline function 'pcg_output_cm_128_64' declared but never defined`
issues.body:
### Describe the issue:

Unlike other functions from `pcg64` which are defined for emulated 128-bit math and non-emulated cases, `pcg_output_cm_128_64` is only defined once:
https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/5f800455a0fb86d4fd33cd93336996e4b00f0414/numpy/random/src/pcg64/pcg64.h#L293-L303
However, it is declared unconditionally: https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/5f800455a0fb86d4fd33cd93336996e4b00f0414/numpy/random/src/pcg64/pcg64.c#L66


### Reproduce the code example:

```python
Run the build, this shows up as a warning.
```

### Error message:

```shell
[269/316] Compiling C object numpy/random/_pcg64.cpython-313-darwin.so.p/src_pcg64_pcg64.c.o
../numpy/random/src/pcg64/pcg64.c:66:24: warning: inline function 'pcg_output_cm_128_64' declared but never defined
   66 | extern inline uint64_t pcg_output_cm_128_64(pcg128_t state);
      |                        ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
```

### Python and NumPy Versions:

python 3.13.7
numpy 2.3.3

### Runtime Environment:

MacPorts

### Context for the issue:

Initially reported in https://github.com/numpy/numpy/issues/29758

issues.title: Followups for same-value casting
issues.body:
Creating an issue for follow up on gh-29129.  Also ping @mhvk because I am sure I'll forget things right now.

Some of these are very concrete, others a bit less so:
* There is now the `_FLAG` which part which is necessary for user dtypes.  We should document at least that flag.
* I am not quite sure, but related, we may need to document the new flag on the context (likely is already)
* The design is in a way so that we *could* thread this cast to all places easily.  Explicitly `np.can_cast` also.
  * @mattip wants to not really do this unless there is a clear user.
  * We might need this, but I am not quite sure. The problem is projects like cupy or so that might rely on e.g. `can_cast`.
   * Other places, where I think it just *clearly* makes sense is e.g. `concatenate` with `dtype=`.
* There is a clear gap that *equiv* casts are always same_value casts.  But for existing dtypes this isn't the case.  It would be good to explore if we can automatically set the flag *for* the dtype.
  * Maybe during registration or in `MinCastSafety`, or... ?

issues.title: BUG: compilation fails when building in custom directory identical to source directory of pyf file
issues.body:
### Describe the issue:

`numpy/f2py/_backends/_meson.py` has an uncaught exception when source and target are identical.

Please find my proposed fix (patch) below.

### Reproduce the code example:

```python
listing essential flags.

after a script creates the fortran source `_interface.f90` in `/home/alex/python/source/multistar/_library`, `f2py -h` creates `_interface.pyf` in same directory, after which I want to build in this directory s well.


python3.13 "-m" "numpy.f2py" "--verbose" "--build-dir" "/home/alex/python/source/multistar/_library" "-c" "-m" "_interface" "/home/alex/python/source/multistar/_library/library.a" "interface.f90" "/home/alex/python/source/multistar/_library/_interface.pyf"
```

### Error message:

```shell
File "/home/alex/Python/lib/python3.13/site-packages/numpy/f2py/_backends/_meson.py", line 188, in compile
    self.sources = _prepare_sources(self.modulename, self.sources, self.build_dir)

    shutil.copy(source, bdir)
    ~~~~~~~~~~~^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "/home/alex/Python/lib/python3.13/shutil.py", line 428, in copy
    copyfile(src, dst, follow_symlinks=follow_symlinks)
```

### Python and NumPy Versions:

  'num_threads': 16,
  'prefix': 'libscipy_openblas',
  'threading_layer': 'pthreads',
  'user_api': 'blas',
  'version': '0.3.30'}]


### Context for the issue:

My script that worked find with `setuptools` now fails with buggy `meson` script.  I raised this issue almost 2 yr ago, including patch, but developers may have overlooked it.

Proposed patch:
in `numpy/f2py/_backends/_meson.py` line 200 replace
```python
            shutil.copy(source, bdir)
```
by
```python
            try:
                shutil.copy(source, bdir)
            except shutil.SameFileError:
                pass

commit.message:
ENH: Run SWIG unit tests in CI action (#30161)

* Replace deprecated unittest.makeSuite() by unittest.TestLoader().loadTestsFromTestCase()

* Do not use negative values in argument of Tensor.<type>Max()

The unit tests involving `<type>TestCase.testMaxWrongDim` do not work for
`<type>` being one of `uchar`, `ushort`, `uint`, `ulong`, and
`ulongLong` (which translate to `uint8`, `uint16`, `uint32`, `uint64`, and
`uint64`, respectively). Instead of raising the expected `TypeError`, the
unit tests raise `OverflowError`, with the error message â€œPython integer -1
out of bounds for <type>â€. This is fixed by replacing the negative values
in the argument of the `max` function by positive ones.

* Run unit tests for the SWIG binding at the end of the sdist job

The unit tests will be run in the Linux workflow using the Makefile
distributed in `tools/swig/test` directory. They are run after installation
of NumPy in the system, ensuring that the C header files are correctly
included (see GitHub issue [#30131](https://github.com/numpy/numpy/issues/30131)).

commit.message: MAINT: fix math markup (\times -> \\times) in numpy.linalg.multidot docstring Notes section

BUG: Avoid compilation error of wrapper file generated with SWIG >= 4.4 (#30128)

The `import_array` macro, which is defined in the file
`numpy/core/code_generators/generate_numpy_api.py`, is intended for use
inside an internal SWIG function that is called in the generated C wrapper
file. This macro contains a return statement whose argument must match the
function definition.

Until version 4.3 of SWIG, the aforementioned function returned a `void*` value.
However, in version 4.4, the return value was changed to `int`. This causes compilation of code using import_array() to fail with the following error message: `returning 'void *' from a function with return type 'int' makes integer from pointer without a cast [-Wint-conversion].`

This commit resolves the issue by returning either `NULL` or `0`, depending
on the SWIG version being used (< 3.4 or >= 3.4, respectively). This change
has been successfully tested against SWIG versions 4.3 and 4.4.

Closes: numpy/numpy#30122

author Rafael LaboissiÃ¨re <rafael@laboissiere.net> 1762105582 +0100
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1762105582 -0700

BUG: Avoid compilation error of wrapper file generated with SWIG >= 4.4 (#30128)

The `import_array` macro, which is defined in the file
`numpy/core/code_generators/generate_numpy_api.py`, is intended for use
inside an internal SWIG function that is called in the generated C wrapper
file. This macro contains a return statement whose argument must match the
function definition.

Until version 4.3 of SWIG, the aforementioned function returned a `void*` value.
However, in version 4.4, the return value was changed to `int`. This causes compilation of code using import_array() to fail with the following error message: `returning 'void *' from a function with return type 'int' makes integer from pointer without a cast [-Wint-conversion].`

This commit resolves the issue by returning either `NULL` or `0`, depending
on the SWIG version being used (< 3.4 or >= 3.4, respectively). This change
has been successfully tested against SWIG versions 4.3 and 4.4.

Closes: numpy/numpy#30122

commit.message:
MAINT: replace use of asanyarray with ... to keep arrays (#29951)

With gh-28576, it has become possible to ensure that when calling a ufunc, the output is guaranteed to be an array.

This PR uses that to replace np.asanyarray calls in some functions. I'm not sure this is complete -- these were just parts of code for which test failed if np.anyarray(scalar) is made to return a read-only array (see gh-29876).

I do think there are all small improvements, though.

commit.message:
This PR reference #11521. It removes deprecated functionality and cleans up outdated code paths:

- Removed the deprecated `style` parameter from `array2string` in `numpy/_core/arrayprint.py`, along with its related documentation and tests.
- Replaced the deprecation warning for `np.sum` called on generators with a `TypeError` in `numpy/_core/fromnumeric.py`, since this behavior is now unsupported.
- Removed a leftover docstring that was intended to be deleted in PR #26268.

* TYP: Annotate ``ma.make_mask_none()``

* TYP: ``ma.core``: move some of the classes to the top (for the sake of sanity)

* TYP: ``ma.core``: introduce a type alias for boolean mask arrays

* TYP: Annotate ``ma.getmaskarray()``

* TYP: Annotate ``ma.getdata()``

* TYP: Annotate ``ma.flatten_structured_array()``

* TYP: Annotate ``ma.masked_invalid()``

* TYP: Annotate ``ma.masked_object()`` and ``ma.masked_values()``

* TYP: Annotate ``ma.*_fill_value()``
